Create jar file and handle empty description error for Event and Deadline
Add assertions to document important assumptions in Parser class
commitResults.messageBody:
Added assertions at key points in the Parser class to ensure important
assumptions hold during runtime. These assertions help catch logical
issues during development by validating the state of variables before
further operations.

- Validate that task numbers and task indices are non-negative to avoid
  index-related issues.
- Validate that in the find method, only one keyword (can be with space)
  is available
- Ensure that event start and end dates are valid and that the start
  date is not after the end date.

These assertions will help during development when assertions are
enabled (-ea flag) and will prevent invalid state progression.

A little bit of refactoring done on Ui.java as well.

commitResults.messageTitle: Codebase contains inconsistent indentation, redundant variables, and non-uniform variable names
commitResults.messageBody:
The current code lacks uniformity in formatting and variable naming,
making it harder to maintain and less readable. Redundant variables
increase complexity without adding value, and inconsistent indentation
makes the code look disorganized.

Improve code readability by correcting indentation, removing redundant
variables, and standardizing variable names. Ensure that all methods
and classes follow a consistent naming convention and appropriate
formatting.

These changes are made to enhance maintainability, making it easier
for developers to read and work with the code. Consistent formatting
and naming conventions also reduce the cognitive load when navigating
the codebase.

This commit does not alter any functionality but focuses solely on
refining code structure and quality.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for mass operations like mark, unmark, and delete tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
The current system requires users to perform task operations one at a
time, making it inefficient to manage a large number of tasks.

Allowing users to perform operations on multiple tasks in one go
improves the efficiency of task management, especially when dealing
with large lists.

Implement mass operations by adding `MassMarkCommand`, `MassUnmarkCommand`,
and `MassDeleteCommand` to handle bulk task actions. These commands
search for tasks based on a keyword, display the matching tasks, and
prompt the user for confirmation before marking, unmarking, or deleting
tasks in bulk.

This approach ensures that users have control over bulk actions through
a confirmation process, reducing the chance of accidental changes.
It also maintains consistency with the existing command processing
flow, ensuring the user experience remains intuitive.

Multi-step user interactions are handled by storing the command state
until the user confirms the action, enabling a smooth multi-step
operation for bulk task management.

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve code styling by reducing nested statements in method getResponse(String input)
Refactor Parser.java by extracting methods in parse()
commitResults.messageBody:
The parse() method in Parser.java is currently too long and contains
multiple responsibilities, making it harder to read and maintain.

This needs to change because it violates the single responsibility
principle and reduces code clarity, making future modifications more
error-prone.

Extract helper methods from the parse() method to shorten it and
improve readability. Group related code into distinct methods to
better separate concerns and follow clean code principles.

This approach is chosen to promote modularity, allowing each extracted
method to handle a specific aspect of the parsing logic. This reduces
cognitive load and enhances testability.

No functional changes are introduced, and this refactor focuses solely
on improving code structure.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add Javadoc comments for command handler methods in Parser.java
commitResults.messageBody:
The command handler methods in Parser.java currently lack Javadoc
comments, which makes it difficult for developers to understand their
purpose, behavior, and usage.

This needs to change to improve code readability and maintainability,
and to ensure the codebase follows best practices for documentation.

Add detailed Javadoc comments for each command handler method,
providing information about parameters, return values, exceptions, and
usage.

This approach is taken to ensure the code is self-documenting, making
it easier for developers to work with the command-handling logic
without needing to examine the method internals. The added comments
enhance future maintainability and onboarding.

No functional changes have been introduced.

commitResults.messageTitle: Correct assertion mistakes in handleMark, handleUnmark, and handleDelete
commitResults.messageBody:
The handleMark, handleUnmark, and handleDelete methods contain
incorrect assertions related to task numbers, which assume task indices
are valid before parsing or validation occurs.

This needs to change because invalid assertions can cause unexpected
behavior and crashes during runtime, especially when handling user
input.

Correct the assertions by ensuring task number validation happens after
input parsing and before assertions are made. Validate the task number
to ensure it is non-negative and within the valid range before
proceeding with the command creation.

This change improves the robustness of the command handlers by
preventing potential crashes caused by incorrect assertions, making the
code more reliable and user-friendly.

No functional changes beyond the corrected assertions have been made.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove redundant String[] parts variable in handleDelete method
commitResults.messageBody:
The handleDelete method in Parser.java contains a redundant String[]
parts variable, which is not necessary for task number extraction and
validation.

This needs to change to simplify the code, improve readability, and
avoid unnecessary variable usage that doesn't contribute to the
functionality.

Remove the redundant parts variable and use the Matcher to extract the
task number directly from the user input. This reduces complexity and
makes the code cleaner without affecting functionality.

This approach ensures that the code is more concise and avoids
unnecessary variable declarations, improving maintainability.

No functional changes are introduced. The code is simply optimized by
removing redundancy.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add User Guide to README.md and correct UI for showUnmarkMessage
commitResults.messageBody:
The README.md file currently lacks a detailed user guide explaining how
to use Hana, including its various commands and features.

This needs to change to provide users with comprehensive instructions
on how to interact with Hana, ensuring they understand how to add,
list, mark, unmark, and delete tasks, as well as perform mass
operations.

Added a detailed user guide in README.md, following the required
format. It includes explanations for adding tasks, marking/unmarking
tasks, and mass operations, with examples and expected outputs.
Additionally, Ui.png was added to enhance the guide with a product
screenshot.

Also, corrected a UI mistake in showUnmarkMessage to ensure the correct
message is displayed when unmarking tasks.

These changes enhance user experience by providing clear documentation
and fixing a UI issue.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove unused Scanner import from Ui.java
commitResults.messageBody:
The Ui.java file currently imports the Scanner class, which is not
being used anywhere in the file.

This needs to change to clean up the code by removing unnecessary
imports, which helps maintain clarity and avoid potential confusion
in the future.

Remove the unused Scanner import statement from Ui.java, as it is
redundant and not required for the current functionality.

This approach is taken to keep the codebase clean, efficient, and
free from unused imports, adhering to best coding practices.

No functionality is affected by this change; it simply improves
code hygiene.
